facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 128 of 1955 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 5, 1953, of the Bombay High Court in I. T. R. No. 40 of 1952.

facts.text: After hearing the parties, the Commissioner passed an order under s. 33B(1) on June 5, 1951 by which he cancelled the registration of the firm under s. 26A and directed the Income-tax Officer to make fresh assessments against the respondent as an unregistered firm for all the three years.

issues.text: Does the order passed by the Income-tax Officer granting registration to the assessee firm continue to be an order passed by the Income-tax Officer even after the assessee's appeal against the assessment made by the Income-tax Officer on the basis that the assessee was a registered firm has been disposed of by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner? In other words, where the appeal preferred by an assessee against his assessment has been considered and decided by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, does the order of registration along with the subsequent order of assessment merge in the appellate order?

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeal two short questions fall to be decided under s. 33B 1 . Does the order passed by the Income-tax Officer granting registration to the assessee firm continue to be an order passed by the Income-tax Officer even after the assessees appeal against the assessment made by the Income-tax Officer on the basis that the assessee was a registered firm has been disposed of by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner ?

issues.text: Whether the order of registration in respect of the assessment year 1949-50 can be made the subject-matter of the exercise of the Commissioner's revisional power even though the assessee's appeal against the assessment for the said year is pending before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner at the material time.

anchor.surface_text: The other question which also falls to be decided is whether the order of registration in respect of the assessment year 1949-50 can be made the subject-matter of the exercise of the Commissioners revisional power even though the assessees appeal against the assessment for the said year is pending before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner at the material time.

holdings.text: We must accordingly hold that the High Court was in error in taking the view that the Commissioner had no authority to set aside the registration order passed by the Income-tax Officer granting registration to the respondent for the years 1947-48 and 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the High Court was in error in taking the view that the Commissioner had no authority to set aside the registration order passed by the Income-tax Officer granting registration to the respondent for the years 1947-48 and 1948-49.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order granting registration is separate and independent from assessment order; not appealable by department under s.30; does not merge in AAC's appellate order on assessment; remains amenable to Commissioner's revisional jurisdiction under s.33B.

holdings.text: We must, therefore, hold that the High Court was also in error in holding that the Commissioner was not authorised in cancelling the order of the respondents registration for the year 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the High Court was also in error in holding that the Commissioner was not authorised in cancelling the order of the respondents registration for the year 1949-50.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pending appeal before AAC does not suspend or merge registration order; department cannot challenge registration in assessee's assessment appeal; s.33B jurisdiction over ITO orders unaffected by pendency.

holdings.text: Therefore we cannot hold that the order passed by the Commissioner is bad in law on the ground that he directed the Income-tax Officer to pass the order in a particular manner. The answer to question No. 2 would accordingly be in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore we cannot hold that the order passed by the Commissioner is bad in law on the ground that he directed the Income-tax Officer to pass the order in a particular manner. The answer to question No. 2 would accordingly be in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Commissioner's direction was merely consequential to cancellation of registration, adjusting machinery/procedure for tax recovery without altering income computation or assessment substance.

holdings.text: We must accordingly answer question No. 3 also in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fresh ITO orders post-cancellation merely changed recovery machinery for unregistered firm; no fresh notices under ss.22/23 required as no fresh assessment or recomputation of income.

holdings.text: The Commissioners revisional power under s. 33B can be exercised only in respect of orders passed by the Income-tax Officer. The appellate orders are outside the purview of s. 33B.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of s.33B(1) limits to ITO orders; distinguished from s.33A which includes subordinates like AAC; registration order is ITO order.

anchor.surface_text: the propriety or the correctness of this order was open to consideration by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner in the respondents appeal then pending before him, Commissioner of Income-tax v. Amritlal Bhogilal subnom   2 . In respect of this order the High Court had framed an additional question. It was in these terms Whether the order of the Commissioner acting under s. 33B 1  setting aside the order of the Income-tax Officer where an appeal against that order was pending before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was valid?

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v Amritlal Bhogilal
precedents.cited_proposition: revisional power cannot be exercised where appeal against the order is pending before Appellate Assistant Commissioner

precedents.citation: Shapurji Pallonji v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay  1

anchor.surface_text: The computation of taxable income is not at all affected by the machinery provided by s. 23 5 . The decision in Shapurji Pallonji v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay  1  on which Mr. Ayyangar himself relied clearly brings out and emphasizes this position. It is true that the Income-tax Officer is empowered to follow the two methods specified in s. 23 5   a  and  b  in determining the tax payable by registered and unregistered firms respectively and making the demand for the tax so found due but this does not affect the computation of taxable income.

precedents.case_name: Shapurji Pallonji v Commissioner of Income Tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: registration of firm affects only the machinery of assessment and collection of tax, not the computation of taxable income

precedents.citation: Rex v. The Special Commissioner of Income-Tax  ex parte Elmhirst   1

anchor.surface_text: In support of this argument Mr. Ayyangar referred us to the decision in Rex v. The Special Commissioner of Income-Tax  ex parte Elmhirst   1 . The point which arose before the Kings Bench Division in this case was whether, when a notice of appeal has been given, it was open to the assessee to withdraw his appeal and the Court held that once notice of appeal is given the appellate authority was entitled and indeed bound to see that a true assessment of the amount of the taxpayers liability was arrived at. We are unable to see how this decision can really help the respondent in the present case.

precedents.case_name: Rex v Special Commissioner of Income Tax ex parte Elmhirst
precedents.cited_proposition: once notice of appeal is given, appellate authority is bound to arrive at true assessment of tax liability

In the result all the questions framed in this case are answered in favour of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioners revisional power under s. 33B can be exercised only in respect of orders passed by the Income-tax Officer. The appellate orders are outside the purview of s. 33B.
In the result all the questions framed in this case are answered in favour of the appellant.
